channel.title: Comments on: Extracting numbers with SQL Server
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Melanie
item.dc:creator: Melanie
item.description: "We all have perfectly normalized tables, with perfectly scrubbed data, right? I wish! Sometimes we are stuck with dirty data in legacy applications. What’s worse is that we are sometimes expected to do interesting things with dirty data." ..That is excatly where i am. Thank you so much sir, this is what i've been looking for the days.
item.content:encoded:
“We all have perfectly normalized tables, with perfectly scrubbed data, right? I wish! Sometimes we are stuck with dirty data in legacy applications. What’s worse is that we are sometimes expected to do interesting things with dirty data.”
..That is excatly where i am. Thank you so much sir, this is what i’ve been looking for the days.

item.title: By: How do I extract part of a string in t-sql - QuestionFocus
item.dc:creator: How do I extract part of a string in t-sql - QuestionFocus

item.title: By: Darren
item.dc:creator: Darren
item.description:
...Answered my own question...
alter Function dbo.GetNumbers(@Data VarChar(8000)) Returns VarChar(8000) AS Begin declare @NoComma varchar(8000) = replace(@data,',','')
Return
Left( SubString(@NoComma, PatIndex('%[0-9.-]%', @NoComma), 8000), PatIndex('%[^0-9.-]%', SubString(@NoComma, PatIndex('%[0-9.-]%', @NoComma), 8000) + 'X')-1) End
item.content:encoded:
…Answered my own question…

alter Function dbo.GetNumbers(@Data VarChar(8000))
Returns VarChar(8000)
AS
Begin
declare @NoComma varchar(8000) = replace(@data,’,’,”)

Return

Left(
SubString(@NoComma, PatIndex(‘%[0-9.-]%’, @NoComma), 8000),
PatIndex(‘%[^0-9.-]%’, SubString(@NoComma, PatIndex(‘%[0-9.-]%’, @NoComma), 8000) + ‘X’)-1)
End

item.title: By: Darren
item.dc:creator: Darren
item.description: Hi, This works great in all cases except where I have a comma as a thousand separator. Where I have '1,000' I get '1' as the result - how can I fix this?
item.content:encoded: Hi, This works great in all cases except where I have a comma as a thousand separator. Where I have ‘1,000’ I get ‘1’ as the result – how can I fix this?

item.title: By: James
item.dc:creator: James
item.description:
I love what you've done here... but using sql server and RegExMatch is powerful and looks a lot neater. I found the following at https://www.simple-talk.com/sql/t-sql-programming/clr-assembly-regex-functions-for-sql-server-by-example/
The equivalent to your Patindex is:
Select dbo.RegExMatch('\d+', YourColumnName,1) as StripNumber
If I can follow his instructions anyone can!!
item.content:encoded:
I love what you’ve done here… but using sql server and RegExMatch is powerful and looks a lot neater. I found the following at https://www.simple-talk.com/sql/t-sql-programming/clr-assembly-regex-functions-for-sql-server-by-example/

The equivalent to your Patindex is:

Select dbo.RegExMatch(‘\d+’, YourColumnName,1) as StripNumber

If I can follow his instructions anyone can!!

item.title: By: Strip text and extract numeric value from string using TSQL | GoldenNugets

item.title: By: DeveloperDan
item.dc:creator: DeveloperDan
item.content:encoded:
The function also fails when a dot appears then text then the number:

‘I found a problem. This text generates a dot instead of a 3.’

I coded an ugly solution. Perhaps you have a clean fix?

item.title: By: DeveloperDan
item.dc:creator: DeveloperDan
item.content:encoded:
Can you suggest a fix that allows the minus symbol to appear away from the number? You code fails with the text:

‘tip-toe 3 steps’

(The function returns just the minus sign, not the number 3)
